article.headline: California 77, Oregon 66
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- Leon Powe got the ball in the opening minutes and saw only one Oregon player guarding him so he took it to the basket for an easy score. "I was happy. I wasn't going to say anything about that. I looked around and said, 'Whoa! It's my lucky night," Powe said. The Ducks' strategy was to play Powe straight up and take away the rest of his California teammates. It might have worked if not for Ayinde Ubaka. Ubaka scored a career-high 29 points and Powe matched his career best with 27 to lead the Golden Bears to a 77-66 victory over Oregon on Thursday night for their third straight win to open the Pac-10 season. "He is such a good player that he is going to get his points," Oregon coach Ernie Kent said of Powe. "Looking at film and watching him being double teamed, he's still capable of scoring. More importantly, he gave so many other people buckets. We did a good job shutting down all their guards but one. Ayinde was a pro tonight." The Golden Bears (9-3, 3-0) got almost no offense from anyone other than Ubaka or Powe -- no one else scored more than seven points -- but didn't need it to hold off the Ducks (7-7, 1-1). "All of us moved the ball pretty well," Powe said. "Anybody could have gotten the points tonight. It was just in our hands and the right place at the right time." The Bears followed up last week's wins at Southern California and UCLA with this victory, giving them their best conference start since winning their first seven games three years ago on their way to the NCAA tournament. "To be where we're at is great. But we still have a lot of basketball to go," coach Ben Braun said. "We sure would like to be where we're at. That's a good spot to be in. But our next challenge is Oregon State." Cal is halfway to last season's Pac-10 win total when the Bears went 6-12 in conference with Powe sidelined all season with a knee injury. The Bears are also all alone in first place after Arizona lost to UCLA on Thursday. "We just have to keep playing good basketball and winning games," Ubaka said. "Anything can happen. Momentum can switch and we could start losing. We can't let it get to us, being in first place." Aaron Brooks scored 18 points and Maarty Leunen added 17 points and 10 rebounds for the Ducks, who haven't won a conference game in the Bay Area since beating Cal on Feb. 12, 2000. The Ducks have lost 11 straight at Cal and Stanford since then. The Bears were in control almost from the start, but the Ducks rallied to cut the lead to 59-52 on a 3-pointer by Bryce Taylor with 4:27 left. Powe then missed at the other end but gathered his own rebound and scored to make it a nine-point game. Ubaka hit a 3-pointer from the top of the key to make it 64-52 and Cal coasted from there. That also gave Ubaka his career-high, surpassing the 21 points he scored earlier this season against Northeastern. Ubaka sprained his left ankle in the second half and his status for Saturday was not immediately known. He shuttled in and out down the stretch. But when the Bears needed big free throws, Braun put him in there and Ubaka made six of six foul shots in the final minute. "I told coach to put him back in," Powe said. "One foot, no foot, zero foot. Doesn't matter." Along with Powe's return from the injury, Ubaka's development as a scorer has been the biggest difference for Cal this season. He hit the big shots down the stretch last weekend in Los Angeles and has more than doubled his output from last season when he averaged 6.1 points per game. Ubaka is averaging 15.2 points per game this season. Powe got off to a fast start, scoring 10 points in the first 3:48, capped by a 3-pointer that ended a 13-2 run that gave the Bears a 15-5 lead. "They are such a good balanced basketball team that you have to pick your poison somewhere," Kent said. "Our key thing was we felt we would have a harder time double teaming him the way they shoot the ball." Ubaka joined Powe in double figures with a jumper just over five minutes later, and no other Cal player even scored until Nikola Knezevic made two free throws to make it 23-11 with 10:03 left in the half. Ubaka (16) and Powe (15) outscored the Ducks as the Bears took a 38-27 lead at the break. Oregon committed 14 fouls in the half, leading to 19 free throws for Cal. Richard Midgley hit a 3-pointer in the second half to move into second place in school history with 158 in his career. Ryan Drew holds the Cal record with 214.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
